{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3441507,"name":"firstrobotcoach","username":"firstrobotcoach","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/f/f04885/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-10-30T04:21:52.433Z","cooked":"

This might be a very weird question, but we are looking at a quick and dirty swerve drive. What I mean by this is we are looking for to buy swerve modules, put them on a drive train and be able to drive it around as a demo robot. Our goal is to have as little programming and electronics on the robot as possible. In the past I have used a Radiolink controller, but I am looking for something that would work with swerve.

Something like this, but this probably would not work for swerve:

andymark.com

RadioLink T8S Wireless Controller & R8EF Receiver

The next generation of robot remote control is here. Want features? It has features, so many features, more than you can count! This eight-channel controller receiver combination works for any and all situations. Connect it via USB micro to a...

Any ideas would be greatly appreciated. Thanks!

I have done similar stuff with kiwi robots.

If you are not super worried about field oriented control you can go very basic with those knock off xbox controllers an arduino and pwm control run open loop. You may need a servo shield for slightly better PWM.

You can add complexity back in with encoders and a cheap well mounted gyro.

Do not forget when coding things up, with basic swerve code (math included), to stop to robot completely if there is no controller input (which can happen a few ways). You likely will need a basic fuse panel of some description for the power side of things no matter what you do.

I agree. It would be nice if we could get a basic swerve version of the mecanum mixer for basic pwm control and 4 quadrature encoders.
